content.body: It's amazing how much smoother to use Gmail is on my tiny Nexus One than on my desktop.
I wonder: is this some deficiency in the web platform, or just Gmail not caching things locally aggressively enough?
bets the latter, wonders why
Local Storage size on disk for mail.google.com: 3 KB for http, 3 KB for https.  :/
hmm the discussions about editors drafts, working drafts, etc. is argueing if it's bad or not
INSTEAD of trying to list the issues/needs and how we solve them.
Issue: working drafts are always out of date
Dashiva: I would add a "for [here an audience]"
for example in your sentence.
Why would anyone want to use an out-of-date draft?
For any purpose?
It's obsolete.
Issue: last drafts of a specification is useful for some implementers.
the only audience for which out of date drafts is useful is spec archeologists, like when henri and i try to work out why something was done
but with HTML5, the whatwg svn repo is far more useful for that now
How do we solve it? What is needed in the document, etc. Editor drafts could be retitled Developers Edition
Resolution: Stop issuing working drafts
Editor's draft covers all the use cases
AryehGregor: People who need stability: Book writers, documentation writers, etc. A lot easier to update your work big by big step than because on a moving target with micro-edits
Dashiva: that's what i did at the whatwg when i realised this problem existed
Should we really be encouraging people to write outdated documentation?
karlcow, why would you want to write a book based on a snapshot that's months out of date?  If you really want that, you can pick a specific revision from SVN and only use that.
At least that will be up-to-date as of the time you start writing.
But I'll stick to stuff written by people who actually follow spec changes, for my part.
AryehGregor: because not everyone is a geek aka pick up a version in SVN
Then why the heck are they writing documentation for a spec?
People who write books and documentation should be competent enough to do so
Dashiva: why do you hate freedom? ;)
nobody's stopping someone from taking a snapshot of the PDF or HTML versions of the spec
I don't hate freedom, I hate freedumb
doesn't mean we need to make explicit copies
just wrote a 1377-word blog comment about HTML5
It is usually wiser for the peace of each community to give tools that these communities need. (if they need it :) )
AryehGregor: 40 words too many!
which blog?
othermaciej, <http://www.cssquirrel.com/2010/06/15/693comic-update-html5-unicorn-heuristics/comment-page-1/#comment-32000>, but it has to pass moderation because of the links I put in for references.
(People are free to be dumb, but we are not obligated to help them)
there's been some interesting discussion in those comments
karlcow, so people who actually want a snapshot can just save the page to their hard disk.  What's the problem with that?
WD would make sense if there were some meaningful procedure for approving it, so it were actually more likely to be correct than an ED, but that's not the case.
othermaciej, I have hopes of converting Kyle Weems to the Light Side.
AryehGregor: I have no issue with people saving a copy, they can do it already :)
I think he's just misinformed.
wishes that people could accept diversity in opinions ;)
Diversity in opinions is fine
Diversity in facts is not
religious statement
too far for me
AryehGregor: I think your messages in those comments come across as fairly rational and balanced
I should probably cite properly
othermaciej, hope so!
AryehGregor: even though you are kind of questioning the quality of my service as chair :-p
The last sentence of my new one is "If the W3C is unwilling to accept that, it will become a victim of natural selection, like it or not", but I think I supported it fairly well.
"You’re entitled to your own opinions. You’re not entitled to your own facts." - Daniel Patrick Moynihan
othermaciej, don't worry, I'm only comparing you unfavorably to Hixie.  That's not an insult in absolute terms.
Dashiva, can I be entitled to my own facts if I write a suitably advanced virtual reality program that implements them?
AryehGregor: that is a lot more reasonable and basically what every society does.
What, writing suitably advanced virtual reality programs?
No, you have to pass a Trial of Philosophy to justify why a virtual reality should be considered factual first
How come these discussions always start hours past midnight
Time to sleep
hehe
Because you live in the wrong time zone?
Dashiva: because you are living in your own reality
CET is the best time zone ever

Dashiva, reality is indistinguishable from a sufficiently good illusion.  Ergo, there is no difference according to any empirical worldview, and empirical worldviews are the only ones that count because all others are stupid.  QED.
Then you have to prove that your virtual reality is sufficiently good
A sort of a turing test, if you will
That was postulated.
"suitably advanced"
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegory_of_the_Cave
Besides, people outside would be able to notice those on the inside, and thereby be able to reject their statements about the warped reality
Dashiva, yes, but that's exactly what we were talking about: everyone gets their own version of the facts.
No, some people get a warped reality and other people get facts
Surely you do not consider the worldview of a lunatic to be factual?
"There will have to be a couple of implementations before CR of HTML5, anyway."
It's like nobody even cares what the process really says anymore
Dashiva, but if everyone uses VR adjusted to taste, then everyone's reality will be equally accurate.
You postulate a world in which a) everyone is in a virtual reality and b) nobody realizes they are in a virtual reality
Sure.  Maybe we're in one already.  Can't say.
Just as good as actual reality.
hehe
Not quite
Even if we cannot say for sure if our reality is indeed reality, we can say for sure that virtual realities inside our own reality are not reality
Dashiva: and it is not an issue

Also, a lunatic's worldview is indistinguishable from a factual worldview, from the lunatic's perspective.  Other people think the opposite, but in principle, that can be a perfectly symmetric disagreement, and we only win by majority vote.
as long as you have developed a coherent system for you and maybe your social groups.
We don't know that virtual realities inside our own reality are not reality if we make ourselves all forget.
Physics (science) is all about *creating* a reality.
I'm speaking from the viewpoint of us after we all go into the VR and forget everything.
If everyone in reality forgets about reality in favor of a virtual reality, then the reality is no longer part of their conceptual universe
In that situation, it would be fair to say that everyone gets to have their own version of reality.
Right, exactly.
as a physicist by training, i have to take objection ot the idea that physics _creates_ reality
Me too, as a physics minor!
Although it would be cool if it did.
unless you have a very odd definition of "reality"
I always play wizards in fantasy games.  :(
That's not very physicsy of you
http://www.w3.org/2010/09/web-on-tv/

No, it's perfectly physicsy.  I'm just utilizing the laws of physics that are present in a hypothetical alternate reality where they allow me to, say, cause you to spontaneously catch fire when I get annoyed at you.
:D
Also known as wish fulfillment
Exactly!
Dashiva: and you are still not in bed.
I actually have both feet in bed
TMI
The bed is my foot stool
The bookshelf is my monitor stand
Awesome, this is how web PDF support should have always been done: http://blog.chromium.org/2010/06/bringing-improved-pdf-support-to-google.html
hmmm, if I can still download the pdf locally or save the generated html on my computer I'm ok.
Browser is not the best tool for me to read a pdf.
I have seen this today too http://simonwillison.net/2010/Jun/17/pdfjs/
I'd way prefer to get a good PDF reader implementation in a browser than to have to use external programs.
AryehGregor: and me the opposite. every taste in nature ;)
Anyway, things I was supposed to do tonight: file health insurance claim, buy several things, study some religious texts, pack for trip, go to bed early.  Things I actually did: chat on IRC.
Sigh.
Good night.
roc
o_O
AryehGregor: nite nite
oops

it doesn't say anything
why do we need a mailing list to discuss browser performance?
roc: I think you should ask plh. I found out through twitter
oh, I thought you W3C people had some sort of cabal
notes to roc that he is not working at W3C
hum
oh well
roc: http://twitter.com/w3c/statuses/16421966743
and the page says "Discussion related to Web browser performance "
I forget -- is there a way to express negation with CSS selectors?
e.g., to express "the first child that is not [something]"?
roc, karlcow - that list is essentially just for discussion of the Web Timing spec
at this point
ah
MikeSmith: thanks. We always need a Mike in one's pocket… hmmm did I write that. I guess so ;)
http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebTiming/
riding on a bus from Tokyo to Nagano is not the best way to get stable Internet connectivity
i love nagano
karlcow: btw, have you been following the current problems with the W3C markup validator
wirepair: I never been there
this will be my first visit
ah nice, it's very very clean air
to Matsumoto, actually
ahh...
i was out in the woods hehe
MikeSmith: about LibXML? I agree with your suggestion

checking the page served as text/html with an html validator. The issue is to give the possibility for people who are working with local document. Upload of an XHTML document. You do not know how it will be served. So in the UI it has to be super clear what is happening
karlcow: I suppose I would not object to having it do XML WF-ness checking on file uploads by default
replied
MikeSmith: have you seen Iwate's Matsuo. Quite impressive. http://www.michaeljohngrist.com/2009/08/the-mist-wreathed-apartments-of-matsuo-mine/
never seen it myself
but I really don't think it's productive for it to be doing XML WF checking on remote docs served as text/html
and iirc the performance problem is for checking of remote docs
yep agreed
I seem to remembers somebody commenting on the validator list that they had no problems if they checked files by upload instead of by HTTP
have not seen
wow, looks great
beautiful decay
yep
"dilapidation's progresses are organized decays"
what's the web on tv workshop trying too accomplish?
hello all
hi

and will it be in chromium, too?
I wish Gecko came with Poppler built-in, but probably not gonna happen due to licensing
AryehGregor: when you say "Firefox currently", do you mean 3.6 and not the trunk?
my notion of current is the trunk
sigh
PFWG persists in their thinking that having three value syntaxes for WAI-ARIA is better than one
that seems like something an overarching body like the TAG could tackle
instead of all this polyglot bullshit
(and with three I mean potentially infinite)
http://twitter.com/simonstl/status/16439272227
yeah, and some part doesn't work in Chrome, and some not in Opera, and some not in Firefox... ooh
And some parts do work in IE6 :P
heh
is disturbed that he seems to have had a dream about breaking and entering Hixie's house
Although I think I was looking for him at the time rather than wanting to steal all his stuff
And I think (although this part is really hazy) I eventually found him but he looked a lot older than in real life
sounds like vacation time :)
also that the PFWG puts DAISY on equal footing with HTML and SVG ... oh well
maybe we should just define the "host blah blah" mapping in HTML5 and use that everywhere and fix the specification to match reality later
that's probably the easier way to fix this
annevk: I think the PF really should focus on Web languages
meanwhile the WOFF people have not read the CORS specification which clearly says the API (@font-face in their case) is in charge of the request semantics whereas they make it dependent on the format

it is becoming quite clear that the reason the web platform is so inconsistent is because nobody really knows how it works but is extending it in their own vision anyway without regards to precedence and design patterns that came before

and in this case not even with regards to things that came before, as CORS is being developed pretty much in line with @font-face / WOFF and is pretty clear on how CORS API specifications ought to work and all
(not that I think it is at all justified that something like @font-face would use CORS, but that is a different matter)
annevk: indeed.
annevk: There's some old stuff that came about by Netscape Netcenter or Bugzilla devs just asking for something and Gecko developers simply said "OK".
wonders if Apple and Opera are taking action on fingerprinting. (see https://panopticlick.eff.org/ )
hsivonen: that's a hard problem
abarth: I think there are easier parts and harder parts.
there are 4 zones: HTTP request, CSS, JS and plug-ins
does it help to do some but not all of them?
abarth: I think it does
presumably that depends on how much information you need to make reliable guesses about identity
abarth: if you do HTTP, you force fingerprinters to expose evidence of their activities to the client
ic
abarth: which means that big players with the widest ability to track people across the Web would be exposed to regulatory solutions
i have a link to the Fingerprint moz wiki page
but i haven't read it yet
my wishful thinking is that the plug-in part can be mitigated by treating everything but Flash as obsolete and by having .swf as click-to-play by default
but I realize this is wishful thinking
also, I have a naive Mac/Linux user POV
I'm saddened to see what kind of NPAPI cruft gets installed on Windows machines

whoa! after a couple of days of having Windows 7 installed and only installing other browsers, security patches, virus scanner and trying to install XP Mode but failing, IE8 running in full screen is already unique
maybe that's because I haven't installed Flash or Java, and not having those is rare
hsivonen: i heard you think about reducing fingerprinting possibilities with http?
hsivonen: any plan what to do there without making half of the webpages unusable? :)
jochen__: well, I filed all the obvious pieces of the HTTP part of the puzzle as bugs yesterday, but I'm not sure where it's going to go
jochen__: as far as I can tell, the only hard part about HTTP request is Accept-Language
mind linking them from wiki.mozzila.org/Fingerprinting?
jochen__: the tracking bug is https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=http-fingerprint
ta
jochen__: I'll add it to teh wiki
oh yeah, OS/CPU is probably politically hard, even though is terms of actual Web compat you get far without them
i see some css selectors are defined in html5 specs, does that mean a request/issues related to that should be expressed in whatwg ml?
or i should use www-style

tabindex=0 enables keyboard navigation for any element. However, I would expect the click event to fire for those elements when pressing Enter/Space while they’re focused. Any reason why that’s not the case?
Enter/Space fires click for every element that’s keyboard-focusable by default
I argued that we should do that
and make onclick="" elements focusable
but not enough browsers did it to begin with so they would first have to be changed as the reasoning, I believe
annevk: Hixie's reasoning, PF reasoning or someone else's reasoning?
Hixie; he just wanted to match reality for now
(though Opera has the nicer behavior afaik)
hsivonen:
hsivonen: Am I missing something?
annevk: Exactly. What Opera does feels like "the right thing"
hsivonen, interesting work on fingerprinting
hsivonen, I think I'll copy some of your bugs and file them on Opera; see what happens
nuking Accept-Charset makes a lot of sense
annevk: the sad part is that there's so much fear of making Firefox lead on this issue. The parts that are the easiest to argue are the ones where IE is already leading... Like Accept-Charset.
jgraham: the
one option is to just revert it into scoping and let the German Figure Collector site break
woah, .Net framework adds itself to Firefox's ua string now too, not just IE :O
daedb: using what mechanism? Whatever ships with Windows 7 doesn't tamper with the UA string of Minefield
everyone wants to add their mark to the UA string :-(
I don't know, but I have "(.NET CLR 3.5.30729)" at the end of my Firefox ua string right now (and Firefox was installed long after .Net 3.5)
daedb: do you see a .Net-specific add-on?
The :net framework assistant, yes, but it's disabled.
hsivonen, the others are more tricky I guess, yes
speaking of HTTP request headers, Opera Mobile on Maemo sure has a long Accept header

hsivonen: worse than everyone wants to add their mark, nobody wants to remove the old ones. the pile is going up, up, up. :) I wonder if there is a physical limit to the size of UA string (characters number)
we cleaned it up a little bit
but then it exploded again ffs
annevk: Opera has cruft in the various Accept headers that clearly isn't critical for Web compat
Accept-Encoding is longer than in IE and Gecko, for example
Accept-Charset advertises UTF-16!!!!
those aren't fingerprinting-relevant, but just saying
hehe
hsivonen, bug on accept-charset is filed
Mozilla has a "guardian of the Accept header", but clearly, there should be "guardian of the UA string, too"
s/, too"/", too/
what is "identity" in A-E? or "sdch" (Chrome has that)
we even have spaces between the values
very generous
annevk: Shared Dictionary Compression over HTTP says the first hit on Google
IIRC, identity is just sending the plain bytes
without compression
http://groups.google.com/group/SDCH
http://www.w3.org/TR/ct-guidelines/#sec-Mobile-DOCTYPES
karlcow: that's sad
reality is sad ;)
filed a bug on Accept-Encoding
"This list is not exhaustive and is likely to change." jaja
karlcow: fortunately, Fennec, Opera Mobile, Opera Mini and Mobile Safari work despite "reality"
2.0 of "Web Content Transformation Proxies" will say they realize now the whole thing is sort of dead
hsivonen: do you mean they are happy? :)
(I'm making that up, but that appears to be reality)
karlcow: they seem happy to me :-)
is making apologizes for his morning syllogism :) still only one eye opened. :)
another thing that is sad is that Accept: is still not */*
annevk: yeah, though it might be wise to wait for IE9 to have been in the market for a while before trying to change that
I thought IE had that since IE6 or so
annevk: I meant the reason not to have Accept: */* is negotiating application/xhtml+xml
but we don't want that :)
if IE9 says */* but support XHTML+SVG *maybe* it'll make Accept-based negotiation less popular
more often than not XML does harm to our end users
what would be the benefit of Accept: */*, because I had a use case in the past where a precise Accept would have helped filtering a DDOS
karlcow: fewer bytes to send, fewer problems for non-IE browsers when webmasters goof
omitting it entirely breaks
my issue was the Accept for GET /blabla resulting from an IMG
karlcow: you should just fix your site :-)
I had no control on it
the ddos was generated by a site with a very high trafic and a bad link.
karlcow: 99.99999% of webmasters wouldn't apply your mitigation method anyway, so it's not useful to support your mitigation method on the browser side
karlcow, you could have done something based on Referer
karlcow: if it was cross-origin, the Origin header will save us

annevk: nope. because it would have removed valid request too :) but I'm more sympathetic to the argument of hsivonen. In the end, we just block the query on that page until we found out where the problem was :)
s/block/blocked/
no it wouldn't
if you just blocked that specific referer for that resource it would've been fine
karlcow: I don't see how it makes sense to talk about a stable snapshot or milestone of an incomplete in-development specification
You can make snapshots and you can assign milestones, but they are arbitrary, not stable
My pet example of why /TR is evil is WebIDL
I have eventually learnt that you can find the actual latest version by being careful about whether you insert a space between Web and IDL in google
karlcow: If you agree about the stable part, wouldn't a permalink in each editor's draft satisfy the snapshot use case?
great, Jonny was already on Accept-Encoding simplification
shouldn't the web timing spec put its stuff on the navigator object?
imagines window.performance is already taken by web authors
yeah, you should say that
putting new stuff on navigator when it is somewhat sensible is better than bloating window even more
there should be a standing memo for spec editors about that
But everyone loves everything being in the global scope, right?
Maybe we need a new parent object for stuff that doesn't really fit on navigator :)
Personally I want more properties on the window object that just refer to the window object
window.Hofstadter for example
Dashiva, the bar for navigator is low enough
god

Dashiva, it could be. :) we just have to find a model which makes it usable for different types of communities and not too burdensome to manage. Often we know our current burden, it's rare we understand the issues we create when changing. But yes it could be a good idea.
karlushi: I am really not sure who the community is that wants a version of the spec with fewer bugfixes in than the current version
I think the stable/editor's draft model is designed around an idea of spec development that doesn't really match reality, at least for the way HTML5 is developed
observes that when document.write() implies a call to document.open() in Gecko, the call is always to the built-in open() and not to whatever the page has replaced open() with
I do not claim reality. ;) Just trying to identify use cases.
karlushi: so what's the use case of reading a spec you know is an already-obsolete draft when you know you could read the latest draft?

That is, if you have stable versions, N, N+1, etc. and unstable drafts at all times t, it only makes sense to promote version N if, on averge, version N is closer to version N+1 than unstable version at time t(N)<t<t(N+1)
hsivonen, will there be at a point a stable version?
karlushi: I expect there will be, but not one that's useful to read
hsivonen, for you and implementers, not useful indeed.
hsivonen, the use case for snapshots is so you can compare what was written at the time of the snapshot with what is now written, which is easier than digging through CVS/SVN logs.
karlushi: It is possible to be unstable, but to be convering on a stable point
Lachy: that's a reasonable use case
translation is another use case. Translating a document which is changing all the time is hell.
karlushi: you just pick the draft that's the most current when you start translating
s/you/one/ who's not necessary a geek.
likes what jgraham is typing now
Heh, putting <plaintext> in <table> so it gets foster parented is amusing
gsnedders: tinfb
is psycic

not gonna happen now

In this case, 3.6; didn't bother to test on trunk because it didn't matter.  I should have specified, though, since it's ambiguous.

My giant comment got accepted.  Everyone feel free to complain about how terribly wrong I am, particularly since I don't have such a good grasp on the history here. http://www.cssquirrel.com/2010/06/15/693comic-update-html5-unicorn-heuristics/comment-page-1/#comment-32000

"this is directly due to completely wrong-headed thinking by the W3C administration."
s/W3C Administration/W3C Members/
Also "The W3C has to this day contributed almost nothing to the spec for practical purposes." makes me huh?
W3C = Members of W3C

if you meant W3C employees have not contributed. Then 1) it's not their primary role. 2) They did contributed in terms of handling all the administrivia of WGs life, liaison, setting mailing lists, web spaces. I would be surprised to consider MikeSmith work = nothing
